55 million, that's approximately
how many meetings there

are across the US every
single business day.

And while there are almost
as many different reasons

for having a meeting
as there meetings,

most still look and
sound like this.
SPEAKER 2: [NON-ENGLISH SPEECH]

SPEAKER: Talking
and more talking.

This time-honored format
often does get the job done,

but it can also lead to a
host of familiar problems.
One person might dominate.
Someone else has checked out.

There can be pressure to listen
to whatever the boss says.

Or the whole thing can
just stray off course.

Fortunately, there
are alternatives.
One sounds like this.
Silence.

Research has shown that
in certain situations,

silent meetings
actually work better.

Specifically, if the
goal of a meeting

is to brainstorm
or solve a problem,

silent meetings have been
shown to generate better ideas.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
But why?

Solutions to a
problem will often

be a novel idea and novel
ideas challenge convention.

They can rock the boat and
make people feel uncomfortable.

But when participants
gather around a table

and generate written
solutions in silence,
a safe space is created.

Novel ideas can emerge
and people are less
afraid of feeling embarrassed.

Silent meetings also circumvent
negative effects of something
called production blocking.

In a conventional meeting, only
one person at a time can speak.

As you wait your turn,
the conversation may shift

and you may lose your
opportunity to raise an idea.

Silent meetings
allow for everyone
to express ideas simultaneously.

So how do you create a
silent brainstorming meeting?

Have people write down their
ideas independently, then

sort them into clusters,
discuss, and vote on the ideas
that people like.

The key is to let the
initial ideation phase happen

independently and in silence
so we can separate egos
from ideas.
Silence is just one alternative.

Since meetings have
different goals,

there's no reason they all
have to look or sound the same.
